reviewText: While watching 'The Hunger Games' I immediately thought of two staple school short stories:  Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery" and "The Most Dangerous Game".  Despite these familiar elements, the author and movie makers make everything else their own.  I like this kind of social science fiction movie because it takes a look at society at large and makes us wince at our worst tendencies (brutality as a spectacle), and contrasts it will a reality wake-up call brimming with common decency.In this near future setting wars and rebellions have ravaged North America, and a police force and other powers that be find that human sacrifice is their solution (not unlike the Mayans).  Although they don't elaborate--at least not in the movie--it seems our near-future world is making pagan sacrifices and providing Coliseum entertainment to a vain and voyeuristic cosmopolitan audience.Twenty-four youth participants (Tributes) are chosen by lottery (where the crowd shows grim resignation.  So much for "What if they had a 'Hunger Games' and nobody played.") and from each district (12) to fight it out in the wilderness with some contrived elements added added to the mix (not unlike 'Survivor 3: Africa - The Complete Season'). While it would be a spoiler to give the details of their feats and challenges, they train in an opulent capitol city, complete with obstacle courses and combat situations.  Harrelson (a sponser and former survivor), Tucci (a slick TV host of the Games), Banks (a gaudy, hyperventilating elite), and Sutherland (perhaps CEO of the Games) play among the status quo, and Jennifer Lawrence and Josh Hutcherson are the young protagonists who add a foil element to contrast the hardened adults.  And, while some of the uglier characteristics are a bit overplayed by the mentioned adult actors, the subtlety is exchanged for a presentation that is sharp and astute enough for our full appreciation.Once they start going the contest is riveting with some character faults and attributes sorting out the contestants.If small extrapolations in science fiction books and movies can make us review and renew our world, then, by golly, I am all for it. This movie is worth seeing as more than food for thought, however, and the movie makers make their point in a way that both makes it easier for us to go along for the ride while we are rooting for their heroes.
summary: A Contest and Contrast Between Brutality and Bravery

reviewText: I'm sure you've read enough reviews telling you how awesome the movie is, so I am focusing on people's complaints.Anything that is missing from the books was because it wasn't that important to the movie, I believe. The mockingjay pin does have a different back story than the book, but it's not that big of a problem; the cornucopia was strange looking, but it was easier to see the struggle on top actually taking place; I do agree Haymitch should have been in it more, but Katniss's struggle in the arena wasn't fully shown and I can understand that it really wasn't necessary to show every little thing that happened.Overall I believe it was a faithful adaption from one of my favorite series. The use of no music was totally unexpected and it's truly genius because you still feel the tension, the heartache, and the love. Another genius idea was to show what was happening outside of the arena. Jennifer Lawrance is Katniss and I'm looking forward to Catching Fire!

reviewText: This review is for the movie independent of the books, as I haven't read them.  Many of my friends have recommended the books to me, but when you read a book and then watch the movie, it is often disappointing, so therefore, I decided to watch the movie first so as to not be biased.  I was seriously disappointed after all of the hype.  I did not enjoy this movie at all.  I understand that it is a dystopia, so it isn't supposed to have a happy ending, but I didn't feel that it was very well done.  I thought the premise was kind of sick.  You have a group of kids and young adults who are randomly selected to go to slaughter, and everyone acts like they are so lucky.  Then people watch as the kids brutally murder each other, and a bunch of other people sit in a control room playing god and screwing with them for fun. I also didn't really connect with the characters.  I didn't feel like the movie did a good job about making the audience care about them.  The whole relationship between Katniss and Peeta was just awkward, and you are left wondering what happened to the guy back home, who is watching as she develops feeling for this other guy.  I have been told that in the book she is only pretending to fall for him, but the movie doesn't give that feeling.  I also found myself feeling uneasy that the target audience is tweens and young adults, and I'm forced to wonder about people who let their kids watch something so violent, where kids killing kids for sport is portrayed in such a matter of fact kind of way.  I am told that in the books, it gives the feeling that it is wrong, but that didn't translate well to screen.  Over all, I found myself wishing for the movie to be over.  It was not entertaining for me at all.

reviewText: To me, The Hunger Games is another chapter in, I hope, a never-ending series of popular, big distribution 'freedom and rebellion' books and movies - think of Star Wars, Firefly/Serenity, Avatar. Such movies and books place a mirror in our face and force us to take a good look at what and who we are and where we seem to be going. We read the books, watch the movies, some of us play the video games and maybe we feel good about ourselves because for a few minutes or a few days or months we 'get it'. Then we return to our real life and hibernate until the next installment arrives. Better than nothing at all and I was happy to see that half of the audience in the theater was made of teenage girls and boys, clearly hungry to experience a story of selfless sacrifice, survival, love of freedom and... love.The movie is as faithful to the book as any 2.5 hours movie covering a book can possibly be. From the point of view of someone who read the book (twice) it didn't take long to find myself immersed in the audio-visual rendition because a lot of what I saw was not unlike what I visualized for myself while reading the bool. Sure, some characters - Cena's crew, the mayor and his daughter - had to be cut out of the story, a couple of characters - Prez. Snow, Seneca - were more emphasized in the movie and there's a little spill-in from the second book in the series but it was all done honestly and gracefully and it was done only because doing so makes it easier for viewers who didn't read the books.The acting and casting are as close to optimal as they can be. Sure, there are some casting distractions - Katniss should not be taller than Peeta and Donald Sutherland is maybe too heavy of a presence for what should have been a slimy and sinister President Snow but everything blends to near perfection eventually and if noticing many in the audience wiping off a tear or two is an indication of immersive story telling then Hunger Games as a movie is very good at telling the story.Hunger Games is one of the not too many mass-market, big budget movies that manage to keep the audience alert and watching for 2.5 hours and leaving the theater feeling good about what they saw and talking about it. And it does so without a lot of CGI, very few explosions. Everyone in my family enjoyed the movie and we are all looking forward to 'Catching Fire' (part 2) of the series and surprisingly, not a lot of graphic violence. As for what's better: reading the book before or after watching the movie, not reading the book at all or not watching the movie if the book was already read... I am happy I've read the book before going to the theater but anyone who enjoyed the movie and hasn't read the book yet I'd say... read it. There's quite a bit more in the book because it's impossible for a movie to show 'everything'.

reviewText: Here we go again:  Storytelling 101 - show your audience, don't TELL them.The Hunger Games is a painful exercise in incessant exposition.  For an action movie built upon the survival instincts of a young and humble warrior, the majority of the film is spent watching people explain things to the heroine and the audience, almost all of which is totally unnecessary.  You don't really need to know about sponsors, apartments, blue hair or the repetitious "Rules of the Game" so to speak. It just ends up dragging what is essentially a 80-minute movie nearly an hour longer.  Despite all the talk of myth that inspired the original novel, we've seen it all before in what is unambiguously adapted from the Most Dangerous Game.Jennifer Lawrence has an honest face which owns every scene, but unfortunately Gary Ross gets it all wrong. Ross cuts to so many arbitrary setups, he seems lost on how to lens and frame this story and by consequence, who to connect with.  You end up not caring who lives or dies in what SHOULD be a story of life and death.  On the dramatic side, we spend more time hearing people jabber on about nonsense than see them act upon anything.  Characters in The Hunger Games seemingly talk AT Katniss, never TO her and it all funnels into unmemorable noise. The empty dialog is shuttled around by lots of unmotivated shaky cam and quick cutting nonsense that doesn't edit.  The movie just doesn't flow well and in the scenes where it finally does - always in action - it is short lived.  At the end of every scene, I was awaiting the commercials because it feels like a hastily produced FOX show for Friday night.I really just wanted to see the young and talented Jennifer Lawrence out in the wild tracking down Arnold Schwarzenegger from the Running Man.  But instead we are held hostage by Gary Ross's witless direction and a dry talky script.  This is a movie with a character but no story, a setup but no payoff. Lots of hunger and very little game.Do yourself a favor, you won't regret it.  WatchHanna [Blu-ray] instead.

reviewText: EDITED AUGUST 19, 2012I bought the DVD of "The Hunger Games" yesterday and watched it for the first time since seeing it in the theater. Looking back on my previous review, I realized I was a little too harsh on the movie. Watching it the second time around, I liked it a lot more than I originally did. However, it's still not without it's flaws. My overall rating for the film is now teetering at about 3.5. Not quite a perfect 4, but not a 3.**SPOILER ALERT**THE GOOD*The acting. This was one of the things I was able to appreciate more watching the movie the second time around. Jennifer Lawrence appears to have been born to play this role. She embodied the role of Katniss perfectly. Josh Hutcherson played a pretty good Peeta. He certainly looks the part, with a round, sweet face. I especially liked him at the beginning, the way he followed Haymitch around like a dog, trying to get tips. I have a few quibbles with him, but overall, really enjoyed his performance. Liam Hemsworth was okay, I guess. It's sort of hard to judge his acting, with what little we were given of Gale (I mean, he wasn't in the book much more, but still.) Most of his scenes were just making angsty faces when Katniss and Peeta kissed.Haymitch (Woody Harrelson) was also perfect. He was exactly how I envisioned Haymitch. I also loved Effie (Elizabeth Banks.) Banks played the airheaded Capitol native well. She had excellent comedic timing with her lines and had a bubbly, vacant personality that was perfect for Effie.(I realize I'm using the word "perfect" a lot.)All of the tributes were also well-cast. Rue (Amandla Stenberg) was absolutely adorable. Cato was scary. His movement throughout the film just seemed to say, "Don't mess with this guy." I liked his monologue at the end, which showed that he wasn't all bad and, like the other tributes, was scared and wanted to go home. Clove was terrifying. The actress who played her was younger than what I imagined Clove in the book to be, but her younger age made her more frightening, with how vicious she was with a knife.Donald Sutherland was different than the Snow I imagined, but that's not a bad thing. I liked that he looked a little more friendly. He looked more like Santa or someone's grandpa. The way he delivered his lines and his voice, though, said otherwise. He was wonderfully creepy.Moving on...*Costumes and makeup. The Capitol's costumes and makeup were insane and I loved it. It was wonderful. It really reflected how silly and airy the Capitol people are. Oh, and some of the hairstyles in this movie. I loved Katniss's hair during the "girl-on-fire" scene was beautiful. Also, Seneca Crane's beard? It made me sad that he died, knowing that I would never see that beautiful beard again. RIP, Seneca.*Glimpses outside the arena. I thought that was a nice touch, since in the book, we're limited to Katniss's perspective. It was interesting to see the Gamemakers add things to the Games. That scene from District 11 was also a nice addition to the movie. In the books, we only hear about a revolution starting via Haymitch telling Katniss and it seems sort of distant. In this, we got to see that the revolution was happening NOW.*Followed the book pretty well. The movie followed the book very well. Of course, not everything was perfect, but what book-to-movie adaptation is? Overall, I was impressed with how the book transferred to the screen.THE BAD*Cinna. Now, he wasn't exactly terrible. My expectations for Lenny Kravitz were kind of low. He surprised me and I'll admit, he didn't seem completely miscast. But something about him still felt kind of...off. I personally feel that Cinna could have been cast better, but like I said, Kravitz wasn't terrible.*The score. It didn't have that broad, epic sound I thought maybe it would have. When a movie is this big, you expect it to have a theme song that will be memorable (think "Harry Potter" or "Lord of the Rings.) I feel that we didn't really get to hear enough of the score, since there were so many silent moments in the movie. What we did hear was, in my personal opinion, just seemed sort of generic, like music you hear in other action/adventure movies. It just didn't really strike me as anything special.THE UGLY*Long awkward silences. At certain points during the Games, the movie goes practically silent or the sound is muffled. Occasionally, it works, but overall, it's just very awkward.*Cinematography. As many other reviewers have mentioned, the cinematography is incredibly shaky. I will praise it for this: It helped with the gore. I think the shaky cinematography eliminated some of the violence. You could tell what was going on, but it didn't get as graphic as it could have. However, it became kind of annoying after a while. I understand what the filmmakers were going for, but I don't think it had the effect that they wanted. It just made some parts difficult to watch. I also wasn't a huge fan of the zoom-ins they did (like when they zoom in on Katniss's lips before she blows up the supplies.) While the cinematography helped tone down the violence, it ended up looking more like a little kid had taped it with a camera.*Games felt rushed. Not horribly so, but I think the movie could have had a little extra time. I think the fandom would have sat through twenty-thirty extra minutes. One part that really suffers, in my opinion, were Rue's scenes. Katniss wakes up, finds Rue, there's a short (and I mean, SHORT) bit showing them eating, then it launches into the blow-up-the-supplies scene where Rue is ultimately killed.*Cave scene. This kind of goes along with the "games felt rushed" problem. I feel like this scene needed a little extra time. It ends up being one of the bigger scenes in the book, with Katniss pretending she loves Peeta, Peeta thinking it's real, and Katniss realizing it might not all be an act. In the end, this scene was mainly just Peeta telling Katniss about his near-lifelong crush on her, along with some rather creepy dialogue. "I watched you walk home from school every day. Every day." Well, hello, Edward Cullen! It also made it seem like Katniss was really, truly in love with Peeta, as opposed to faking it, although I will say that towards the end, when they come home to District 12, she seems a little awkward with Peeta.Overall, this certainly wasn't a bad movie. It was a good adaptation of the book with some amazing acting. But it did have its flaws and it wasn't perfect. However, I think fans will enjoy the movie.
summary: The Hunger Games: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

reviewText: I'll admit I was prompted to watch The Hunger Games because of the hype generated mostly by my daughter. She read the book, I didn't. The movie has high and low moments. There are some scenes that play out with nail biting interest that top many an adult oriented action flick. The low point scenes like an assailant that has to talk to Katness before killing her (typical chance to be saved)and weak CGI beasts that would have killed the duo hurt the film and push it into kid land from an adult perspective.The elaborate look of the film reaches grand moments along with some top notch survival acts. I do see where the appeal lies for the youth and I also see as an adult a little too much tv series style angst. Keeping the target audience in mind, it's an entertaining film. Watching the extras I was informed that Suzzane Collins who authored the book supposedly based the storyline of the ultra rich against the ultra poor on the Bush era worldview. I would say the class warfare interjection concept could be easily applied to the current White House occupant as well.The extras were also geared surprisingly towards adult viewing which I enjoyed. Donald Sutherland excelled with another creepy authoritative role and Woody Harelson was better than he has been with a realistic mixed bag persona. Jennifer Lawrence held the film together with appropriate emotions that made you want her to exceed.Josh Hutcherson as the boyfriend with a crush was a "seen it done before" portrayal. A few sub characters needed to brush up on the acting chops as well. All said and done, The Hunger Games mostly succeeds, you can watch it with the kids and end up with a discussion on the perils of life.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I liked the movie.  I saw it twice in theaters--and when the DVD comes out this August I plan to buy it.But I got sea sick watching the movie.  Two hours and twenty-two minutes of fuzzy focus channel surfing by trembling cameramen made "The Hunger Games" hard to watch.  Motion picture cameras are NOT cocktail shakers, people!  The number of cuts per minute must have shattered some records, too.  Like I said, channel surfing by drunk camera operators...Rue's death scene in the movie is fare better than what I imagined from reading the book.  The interveiw segment with Katniss and her red dress was special.  The screen showed a better "girl on fire" than I imagined from reading the book.  It's a worthwhile movie--marred by vibrating images.  The artistic decision to shake the camera detracted from the scene when Katniss suffers jacker tracker hallucinations because the images already suggested that the audience was intoxicated.It can't be fixed now--but perhaps the director and editor will pay attention to my lone voice and use better camera techniques for the release of "Catching Fire" in November 2013.

reviewText: I postponed watching this film for quite a while, but finally watched it; it was every bit as awful as I feared it would be.  I simply cannot believe that this is what passes for teen inspiration and role models today. Oh, wait a minute: yes, I can believe that our bloodthirsty culture industry will peddle this kind of crap to passive consumers. The messages contained in this film are horrifying: who on earth came up with the idea that kids killing kids creates winners and heroes? Sounds like a great idea for terrorists...In my mind, there is absolutely nothing redeeming about this franchise, and I think the book author and everyone involved in this project are monstrous in that they greedily inflict these messages on teenagers: winning at any cost is good; killing bad teenagers is good; resistance is futile but noble in some pathetic way (as long as you still smile and wave for the camera); and ultimately, give the authorities what they want.TEENAGERS MURDERING TEENAGERS: Whodathunk that this would be the positive message for teens in 2012? Sick, pathetic and mind-numbing. Ours is one pathological culture, its very own axis of evil.

reviewText: I understand that there was a civil war and that the rebellious districts lost. I understand that to the victor go the spoils. I don't understand how the hunger games do anything whatsoever to benefit the victor. Tribute in the form of forced labor or forfeited wealth I can understand. Tribute in the form of kids killing each other doesn't seem like smart resource management. Subjugating and oppressing the rebels is one thing. Pissing them off by making their kids kill each other seems like a certain recipe for further rebellion. Intimidate the districts by giving them a spark of hope because "hope is stronger than fear"? Does that make even the slightest bit of sense?Even assuming the districts put up with this nonsense, what's with the lottery? Why wouldn't there always be a volunteer? Has the world changed so much that districts don't have goth kids who want to die or jocks who want to prove their manhood? If victory is the ticket out of a life of assured misery, I'd expected dozens of kids to volunteer for the games.With such a preposterous premise, why am I giving The Hunger Games four stars? Because, premise aside, it's a riveting movie. In the end, I was willing to forgive the premise because there's so much here to like.I loved the editing. The quick jumps from scene to scene give the film energy, even early in the movie when nothing much is happening. The camera's brief focus on held hands and grim faces tell the viewer more about the people of District 12 than an hour of dialog would manage, and in a more meaningful way. During action scenes, close-ups are used effectively to heighten tension. It's just a pleasure to watch, and get lost in, the action.I loved the performances. Jennifer Lawrence sold me. Woody Harrelson sold me. Josh Hutcherson convinced me that he's not just a pretty face.I loved Stanley Tucci's hair.I even liked the writing. It's subtle when it needs to be. It isn't cheesy. I love the way the movie conveys emotions without using words.The whole rule change shtick is a little ridiculous -- our favorite characters didn't see the second change coming? They're smarter than that. The game managers' ability to create beasts out of -- what? -- is senseless. Again, I'm willing to forgive the silliness because I enjoyed the movie so much. Can't help it, I just did.

reviewText: The post-apocalyptic storyline is great, but the juxtaposition of the natural environment with the high-tech digital reality of the games was just too jarring. The scenes with the dog-like creatures in the end just made you think that the controllers of the games could have made any outcome work, so it took away from the cunning and resiliency of the contestants. Not sure how this was handled in the book, but it just didn't translate that well to the screen.  The movie was a great tale of resistance against powerful and completely degenerate leadership, so it was worth it, and the natural setting in the western North Carolina mountains was beautifully filmed.  I just found the Sci-Fi elements distracting from the movie's message. Jennifer Lawrence is very impressive here, but she plays pretty much the same character to better effect in "Winter's Bone."

reviewText: I happened to see the movie during a flight back from overseas. Since I was travelling in Busniess class I believe I saw it in its entirety (2hrs 20 mins or so). A friend has been talking about this movie and the books for some time now and I decided to watch it and form my own opinion. The movie did hold my attetnion from beginning to end but there were so many "holes" in the plot that I could not help myself from noticing. One of the biggest issues in the movie is the disparity of the ages of the contestants! How could a 12 year old boy or girl ever go against an 18 year old one? The whole idea is beyond absurd and I am not one having issues with "far off" ideas. Still, during the whole movie I kept being reminded that sompething must be really wrong with the whole human race watching their kids getting slaughtered like animals. How long would a dictatorship like this last if they messed around with a society's chil;dren? And why children in the first place?Another part of the movie I had a serious issue with is the "blood bath" at the beginning of the HGs! Some kids almost acted like expert killers having no issue what-so-ever to gut another human being. Totally unbelievable because there is no precedence in the movie to indicate a society that was in such chaos.Anyway, i am undecided whether I liked this movie or not. Cinematography was great, and the score especially at the endof the movie stuck in my head like a dream. I guess I should go ahead and read the book in order to see where the movie is coming from. My opinion might change then...

reviewText: Immediately engaging with thought provoking effect that lingers.  The character who created the most interest throughout was Peeta - in the book and the movie, but the story and characters are well-developed. The idea of a central government that uses its people badly is an old historical reality that always needs a new expression and a new audience.  The stark contrast of people who waste to the point of disgust beside the poor districts where people are starving is an excellent tool for raising awareness in young people when they become aware of local and world politics.The costuming was a bit of comic relief and was also effective is showing the difference in quality and talent versus the fast-paced wanna be world.  Overall, this is a great blend of intrigue and social commentary.

reviewText: Despite a cast of fine actors, this film was not very impressive. First of all, the plot steals largely from Kinji Fukasaku's 2000 masterpieceBattle Royale(based on the 1999 novel by Koushun Takami). Secondly, this film -- while recycling that plot -- merely adds in a bunch of weird costumes, a love triangle and several little side plots that take away from the main point of the film. Don't forget that this is a story about youngsters forced to kill each other. That should be the central focus of the story, which it is inBattle Royale: The Novel; however, in "Games," the deaths (except for one that contributes to the emotional intensity of the story) quickly flash by on screen. I'm sure the movie team did this so they could get the PG-13 rating and rake in more kids to the box office. And while I'm sure parents and kids alike probably will appreciate this, I think it steals away from the seriousness of the situation. I have not read the book and can only hope that the lives in there are not simply a quick, few sentences. But, in the film, by flashing through the deaths, it's as if the filmmakers are saying that the lives of those lost is not really that important. Also, the budding romance between Katniss and Peeta is too distracting and takes up too much valuable screen time. It makes the audience forget what this film is ultimately about: kids being forced to kill one another! I know this is a trilogy so this is merely the beginning and the story is being set up, but it's a poor first act. Even the predictable outcome of the two leads is a bit forced and unrealistic. The only character with any credibility in the story is Harrelson's Haymitch Abernathy. Now, if there were an entire novel/movie about his winning the games and what lead to him being the way he is in this story, THAT would be a film worth making! As I said, want a film that has the same plot but better writing, direction and music? Check outBattle Royale: The Complete Collection!
summary: Want to see the original, better film? See "Battle Royale"!

reviewText: Ok, I get it, people don't really care about good film making ultimately. And there is something that people responded to in this film, but I don't know what it could be.I read all the books, and really enjoyed them. The books should translate to a film fairly well. They are practically written as a screenplay. But even saying that, I did not watch this film expecting a match to the book, or even a perfect matching of the characters. I was ready to just see a good film, regardless of how true to the book they were.This is not even worthy of being called a film. It is some kind of cheap presentation. Something you'd see at a tourist attraction in a crappy little theater where someone shook the seats and sprayed mist in the air under the premise you were watching a "Senseorama" demonstration.Horrible screenwriting, horrible acting, horrible casting, non-existant cinematography, editing that feels like the result of some kind of computer algorithm that just mixes up shots randomly to music and dialogue, and seriously low budget visual FX. At least those crappy Transformer films get the FX right.There is no film making craft visible in this picture, it needs to be categorized as something else. It's not even on par with cheap and cheesy TV movie of the week style story telling. This is barely on par with most video game cut scenes.If you have any respect or admiration for cinema craft, do not waste your time sitting through this abomination.

reviewText: It took me long enough, but I finally caved and saw `The Hunger Games'.  I'd read the book late last year and have since then intended on seeing the film but had just never gotten around to it.  I'll say pretty much what I had said in my review of the book; if you have a problem with the nature of the material then don't watch the film.  I mean, it's not like the themes here or the general plot itself isn't wholly explained on the outset.  You aren't going to be surprised by the violence since it is widely known and publicly criticized.  If you watch the movie or read the book then you have no grounds to complain about the violence.You've been warned.That said, I totally get the criticisms or the media and our society in actually targeting our youth with this `entertainment'.  Kids killing kids isn't something I think children should be entertaining themselves with.I watched it though, so I can't say much.For me, the film doesn't quite hold up against the book, which delves deeper into the political aspects of the films themes.  It actually speaks to a more socially conscious narrative than one would assume.  Sadly, the film attempts to condense and provide the audience with a more streamlined `action film' and because of this it changes up key segments and creates a less arresting experience.  The technical aspects of the film are also a letdown since they distract from the action.  The fire in particular is embarrassingly bad.  Still, Lawrence is exceptionally good here.  She cycles Katniss's emotional range with expertise.  The cheeky gaudiness of it all is engaging, but some of the rougher edges of the film really distract.  The jeering of the kids is so fake feeling, and the underdeveloped plotting of the `villains' is just too much of a head-sore.  The book was much better than I imagined and the film was more underwhelming than I imagined.It's good, but that's about where it lies.

reviewText: This movie is simply way over rated. The over hyping of the movie itself already misleads people. It gives people a pretty high expectation for the movie, so if's the movie is okay, we'll feel that it's a bad one (worse than okay). If the movie is bad, we'll feel it's really bad one.And here are the reasons of why this movie itself (without any consideration of its overhyping around it):Spoilers below1. People say that Katniss issuch a great character with all her heart, mentality, and skills. The "heart" part, I agree. The "mentality" and "skills" part, I don't agree at all. Both her mentality and skills are not consistent, in this movie at least (I never read the book, that's why I'm reviewing the movie only ;p)Examples: I don't think replacing her younger sister is a super noble move at all, that's what a big sister or brother do anyway, except the older sibling feel that they can't win at all or doesn't care at allor worse, both. Okay, let's say it's a noble/bold move, then what? With the Hunger Games already going on year after year, they are suppossed to be prepared mentally and strategy wise! She hasn't prepared anything for the games except her hunting skills?? No strategy, no other kind of martial art or self defense at all? That's not consitent and doesn't make sense.She also get a lot of help: from the mentor when he sent the cream in her hiding to heal her open wound, Peeta's help when he persuaded the "bad group" to leave her and let her tired while he gave her chance to escape and plan soemething better, and also the little girl who's smart and idolize her, she also helped our so called great main character. So she's not that good actually. Even with all those helps, she barely made it.And how come his mentor can send in help like that? If the hunger game president really doesn' twnat to give the poor (district 12) too much hope, then he'll hold Katniss' mentor to be responsible for some kind of punishment, since it's not fair, especially against the president's will (we can see how he wants to control the outcome of the game).2. The fighting scenes is so annoying!! The camera work are worse than if a 5 year old holding a video camera and trying to film an MMA match! It keeps shaking so bad and going everywhere! And I am not exaggerating at all, it is that bad!!3. The movie is way too slow and too long. Recently, this become a trend for a so called big and great movie (I called them overhyped), examples of other movies which are way too slow and long (both great or bad movies): Transformers series, The dark Knight Rises, Battleship, etc. Why come back to the old school wy of presenting movies? Remember when we watch old James Bond series still played by great Sean Connery, awesome Roger Moore? They are great James Bond movies, just way too slow and long (4 minute on underwater diving scene, etc.). The James Bond movies played by Pierce Brosnan and Daniel Craig are pretty way faster pace.On top of all that, it's way overhyped, then it'll mislead people to have a very high expectation, so I was about to rate this movie 1 star but again, after I cool down from the overhyped, I just review the movie itself without the overhyping, I give it 2 stars.Ooh, one more. Why do they have to use children to figth to the death? Just use adult to fight to the death? That idea also makes me sick, seeing what they intended to be 12-16 year old killing each other (this question is more for the author of teh book, Suzanne Collins ;p)Anyway, the movie itself is okay. But with the idea and teh overhyping, it's getting worse. Just be prepared.

reviewText: I loved the books, so I was a bit apprehensive about how a movie version would fare.  However, I was pleasantly surprised at how well the casting turned out.I had not heard of Jennifer Lawrence nor seen any of her work before she was cast into this movie.  I think that she made a great Katniss Everdeen.  She really embraced the role of a girl who had the weight of the world on her shoulders.  I love LOVE Stanley Tucci as an actor and he was perfect in his role as well.  I usually cannot stand Woody Harrelson, but he didn't bother me at all in this movie.  I think his Haymitch might turn out quite well.  And as much as I loathe Donald Sutherland, he made a perfect President Snow.I do think that if you haven't read the book, the story may be a bit hard to follow, as they do have to skip through some sections of the book in order to keep the movie at a reasonable length.  You miss a lot of the interaction between Katniss and Peeta. But I think that they did the best they could within the time limitations.Highly recommend.

reviewText: Jennifer Lawrence, though quite good in other movies, such as the X-Men series, is lame in this completely unconvincing adaptation of the popular kids book, "The Hunger Games." The book itself was, while geared to teenagers (or tweens), was entertaining enough to keep readers' attention and plausible, though a bit heavy handed with the allegory.This movie version drops all the subtleties and just proceeds with the action, and that action is stilted and unbelievable. Woody Harrelson does a credible job, though his character has changed from the book version, and other characters are barely developed. Everyone knows the story from the beginning and knows Catniss will prevail, so there's little drama, and her cohort is horribly miscast. Even the usually capable Lawrence doesn't quite seem how to play the role she has been cast in, and the result is a mishmash of action and internal angst that is poorly portrayed.The script is terrible, the story has been stripped of human interest, and the allegory is unbelievable. Despite all the hype, this is not a worthwhile movie.

reviewText: Synopsis: general: in a (presumably) future dystopia, a country is divided into about a dozen districts, all under the heel of an autocratic central government. Decades ago, a revolt was put down and one of the results is that each district must annually present two tributes to the central government to fight to the death until only one survives, who is then rewarded. In this way, a certain degree of divide and conquer is maintained by the central government. The gladiator combat is televised and has become such an obsession in the society that our obsession with football/soccer/basketball pales by comparison.Synopsis: specific: out of dirt-poor District 12 a girl substitutes herself for her younger sister, who would obviously last all of ten seconds in the arena. The older sister (Katniss) is adept at the bow and arrow, so she may stand a chance. She and the boy are sent to the capital, where food and luxury are abundant. The inhabitants of the capital have makeup and dress as if Salvador Dali and Lady Gaga had been given the run of the place. All tributes are treated as celebrities, and participate in training and in-depth interviews conducted by Ceasar Flickerman, sporting an outrageous outfit and wig and played by Stanley Tucci, a character actor whose star has lately been rising rapidly. Throughout, none of the adults seem to appreciate the immorality of the situation; it just does not register with these people. Ultimately, Katniss is sent to the outdoor arena where she has to survive her vicious opponents. The weak tributes are dispatched quickly by the others and then it is her turn. However, her personality is a bit unique and this comes to her advantage. In order not to spoil the movie, I will stop here.This film is an adaptation of the poorly-written novel by the same title; it is better than the book on several levels. Aside from the writing style, the book is written in first person, but the movie has scenes that she could not be a part of but which help the movie, particularly the meetings between the people who pull the strings.Overall, a pretty good dystopian movie. Unlike the majority of the genre, it does have a happy ending.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What doomed this movie was the low budget.  While the book had its moments of cliche and trope abuse, it also managed to put a spin on most of them.  The film?  Not so much.This is not a movie that can be enjoyed by someone who didn't read the book.  Too much of the background, exploration of the setting (if one doesn't know about District 13, the reason for the Games falls apart.), of the characters, was scuttled.In every instance where we're supposed to be overwhelmed by the decadence of the Capital, the jaded elite who view the Games and make their livings by it, the movie manages to trip over its own feet and fall flat.  The entire train sequence, where Katniss and Peeta are supposed to be overwhelmed by the sheer luxury and the sheer amount of food available flopped--because what we saw looked more like the free continental breakfast you get at a Comfort Inn.  All of the key relationships have been scraped down to the bare bones development-wise.  A movie viewer gets *no* sense of why Katniss and her mother have the relationship they do, why some people put their names in for consideration more than once (a critical detail!)  Effie's character was reduced to a mere caricature, which was criminally stupid.  Donald Sutherland was *wasted* in this movie.  I hope he got a lot of money to make up for having to perform such a narrow, limited role.  The real horror of the dogs (muttations, to use the book's term), even the arena itself, got whitewashed.  Oddly, I'm most disappointed in the presentation of the Cornucopia--I was expecting a huge golden structure, not something that looked like it got dragged out of a railyard scrap heap.The only thing that made me sit up and take notice was the riot in District 11.  That, and Cato's penultimate scene at the Cornucopia--I actually felt sorry for him.  The soundtrack/score tried very hard to deliver, but at its best, it never went beyond late-80's one-hit wonder level.I saw this for free through Amazon Prime.  I got what I paid for:  nothing.

reviewText: There was so much hype surrounding this film that I really wasn't sure what to expect. The film is a great satire of reality television and it takes the concept behind shows like Survivor to the most extreme conclusion.  I really enjoyed this aspect of it, but I didn't think it was critical enough of the horrifying spectacle of children killing each other for sport.Apart from one character right at the beginning (I can't remember his name) who says that people should stop watching the Hunger Games, no one else in the entire film raises any kind of moral objection to the show or suggests any way of putting an end to the madness. I know viewers are meant to know the Hunger Games are barbaric and disgusting without it being spelled out, but I found it very hard to relate to characters like Woody Harrelson, who we are supposed to like, when they are so complicit with the murder of children. Katniss also never contemplates trying to escape, or does anything to stop the killings. Personally I'd prefer a heroine with more guts.It also seems ironic, not to mention hypocritical, to make a film about the horror of mudering children for entertainment when the movie itself is based on the murder of children for entertainment. We see them sliced and diced, and apart from the few characters we get to know, their deaths are not seen as tragic or horrifying. To make it more palatable many of the other tribues are portrayed as evil sadists who totally enjoy murdering their competitors. They band together and laugh and joke as they kill people, seemingly oblivious to the fact that they will be next. This wasn't realistic at all.I'm told the book is much better than the film, and I can see how some of the faults of the film come from adapting it from a novel. I really wanted more background history for this society which could be civilised in some ways and barbaric in others. Without this context it just doesn't ring true. I also found the characters pretty one-dimensional to be honest. Despite the fact that it's quite a long movie I never felt it delved very deeply into their psyches and I really didn't care that much for them.It sounds like I hated this movie, but I didn't. I thought it was okay, even if it didn't live up to the hype. I'll watch the next one that comes out just to find out where it is going because the ending was quite ambiguous. 2.5 stars.
summary: Doesn't Live Up To The Hype

reviewText: Post-apocalyptic North America is controlled by Panem, a dictatorial state which enforces control through discipline and fear. Every year, two 'tributes' from each of Panem's twelve districts are chosen at random to do battle to the death. The survivor of the carnage becomes rich and famous, and the people are reminded of the Capitol's power. Sixteen-year-old Katniss Everdeen volunteers to take her sister's place in the games, and must find a way to win despite her lack of experience and training.The Hunger Games is an adaptation of Suzanne Collins's YA novel of the same name and closely follows the events of the novel. Like the book, the film pits Katniss Everdeen in a fight to the death against twenty-three other youngsters, including her fellow contestant from District 12, Peeta Mellark. The story is divided into two distinct sections, the first involving Katniss's selection and preparation for the games and the second depicting the contest itself. This shift in setting and tone halfway through the film helps sustain and the tension and drama through the movie's running time (which, at almost two and a half hours, is fairly long for a YA movie).The script closely follows the plot of the novel, apart from a fairly elegant solution to the problem of the book being based on Katniss's heavily-internalised experiences. In the novel Katniss can only speculate on the motives of the people running the game, but in the film we cut away to what's going on the game control centre and with President Snow. This expands the scope of the film a little and helps set up the sequels rather better than the novel, which was not written with sequels in mind and didn't layer in a lot of foreshadowing for what would come after.The movie follows the book in presenting the Hunger Games as a satire on modern reality TV shows, but through the visual medium is able to take this a lot further through film clips of people commentating on the game like it was the latest season of The X-Factor. Unfortunately, rather like the book, the film also does not take this satirical edge far enough, instead opting for raising questions and then not exploring them far enough. This problem also extends to the story's use of violence and morality. As in the novel, Katniss and Peeta are never put into a position of having to kill any of the other victims of the game, only the 'bad guys' who revel in it. The movie cops out on putting Katniss and Peeter in real moral quandaries, which is a shame. The film also has variable CGI, with depictions of the Capitol's cityscape looking decidedly sub-par in places.Aside from that, the film works pretty well. The movie is quite long but there's a lot of plot to fit in. Director Gary Ross has a crip, fast-paced directing style that moves us through the novel's major story beats without sacrificing too much atmosphere. He often finds concise ways of giving us backstory and worldbuilding information without having to waste time on exposition, which keeps things moving along nicely.Performances are pretty good. The movie hinges on Jennifer Lawrence's portrayal of Katniss and she nails the role perfectly, bringing the required mixture of anger, determination, bravery and guilelessness. Josh Hutcherson has to settle for merely being good in the role of Peeta, with more established performers like Stanley Tucci, Toby Jones, Elizabeth Banks, Woody Harrelson and, of course, Donald Sutherland fufilling their roles with aplomb. Sutherland brings an air of real menace to the role of President Snow that bodes well for the sequels. Lenny Kravitz also impresses in the role of Cinna, though this role has been cut down from the books somewhat.With a good script, economic story-telling and solid performances, The Hunger Games (***) is overall an enjoyable movie. It loses some of the depth of the secondary characters and subplots over the novels, but on every other level is a very respectable adaptation. It is available now in the UK (DVD, Blu-Ray) and USA (DVD, Blu-Ray).
summary: Entertaining fun, but pulls its punches a few times

reviewText: I didn't really think this movie would be my cup of tea as it seemed to have a teenage or young adult target audience.  However, after seeing Jennifer Lawrence nominated for so many awards this year, I decided to see where it all started.  Guess what!  Although I am a senior citizen, this was a fun, exciting movie which I really enjoyed.  The premise of the movie was sort of a "Star Trekkie" type challenge which seems to pop up frequently in science fiction movies.  Hunting humans instead of animals has long been a theme in literature and has always seemed hard to believe for me.  But, when you see how Katniss is forced into the games to protect her beloved little sister, it is no far fetched.  And, you can see the "evil government" using these games to exert authority over the populace.  It IS believable.  So, all in all, it was a good story and Katniss is a character you cheer for.

reviewText: I had high hopes that this movie would be good, but it was not.The story I found to be shallow. The country is divided into districts. Each one of these districts as a punishment for losing in a civil war has to provide two gladiators. All these gladiators have to fight to the death in a contest that is a reality TV show. It made little sense. As the film itself shows it is not a policy that passives the locals. Nor are many of the people selected the type that would produce a sporting contest that people would want to watch. We are talking here a blood sport and people that like to see blood sports want to see action. Many of these people did not even know how to fight. Many selected did not want to fight and tried to avoid it. What is the point for the viewer, to see such contestants.Nor did it make much sense as the game started to move away from the objective of the producers of this contest that the rules be changed. Surely, after seventy years it is supposed to be going, they would be extremely unlikely to change the rules.Furthermore, the action scenes are weak. If you are going to show a blood sport I would expect some real battles, some brutal scenes. Something more like Blood Royale.Nor do I see where all this money was suppose to be spent, the actual filming, I thought could have been better,  I would describe it as ordinary.  Surprisingly to me, the special effects were ordinary - no wow factor.The acting was generally good. The woman who played Katniss, I thought was good although not convincing as an action hero. Others such as Haymitch and Cinna played well.If you have kids, I would suggest it, other then that NO.
summary: PG rating ruins such a movie

reviewText: I enjoyed the book very much and for the past several months have anticipated its adaptation to the screen.So is it worth it? I would say so. The book is much better(as in most book to movie translations)but it did entertain and stay true to the book. Only a few minute changes were made, that's all, I wont say what. What I will say is that 'It did not show enough violence', yes, its PG-13, but we know the consensus, show the brutality of what the future dystopia is like.The camera movement was awful and inconsistent at times, as well as the editing, which disrupted the flow of the story. I do not recommend doing a sequel, but I'm sure its inevitable.The only really good accomplishment is the cast and the acting. There were great performances in here, this keeps you in the film(No Twilight acting here) I was touched and my eyes may have had a slight discharge at the Rue and Katniss scene, which was done wonderfully. Peeta and Katnis had great chemistry together and fine performances by Woody Harrelson, Stanley Tucci and Elizabeth Banks was superb as Effie Trinket. Not enough Cinna, but Lenny Kravitz was great.It was OK but no 'Battle Royale' or 'Lord Of The Flies'
summary: An OK but not great adaptation, but nothing really new here.

reviewText: Great fun to watch and kept me on the edge of my seat because you really don't know what's going to happen from one moment to the next. "The Hunger Games” builds on stories deep in our collective databanks, from the Greek myth of the Minotaur to the fall of Rome, and “Survivor,” the seemingly indestructible reality TV franchise.  Like the 2000 Japanese movie “Battle Royale,” to which it bears some resemblance, “The Hunger Games” works because it hits that sweet spot where classical myth meets contemporary anxiety to become a pop mind-blower.

reviewText: Normally I dont leave such a long review, but for this I had to...The movie, if you have not read the book, is good.  Its action packed!  It's a different kind of move with lots of eye catching scene's.  However, if you have read the book...get ready!Once the film was over...I was actually angry!  I feel they did a HUGE disservice to the book, the author and mainly the characters.  It's like talking about history and saying that the World War's were just wars, talking about the depression as just a hard time,  saying Romeo & Juliet were just trying to tick their parents off and were not really in love.  Yes it kept with the `Main' premise of Panam & the Hunger Games, but it couldn't tie them together at all since they left all the relationships out of the film.  Furthermore they tried to tie up the main book in one movie when it should have been in 2 parts (good on twilight directors for doing this).  They left out the main relationships with Katniss and Gale (they were not just friends & not just teenagers), Katniss and her mother (why Katniss hated her mother), Katniss & the village (btw that mockinjay pin-NOT BOUGHT AT THE HOB!), the whole train scene which is a HUGE part of the story that sets the stage for everything between Peeta and Katniss & Katniss & her Prep Crew/Cinna, & Katniss/Peeta & Haymitch. I mean even Effie was cut in half with her relationships!  I was furious at the way they in the film took Katniss & Peeta's relationship and made it look superficial, forced and only for show!  It should have said LOOSLEY BASED ON MAJOR  EVENTS IN THE BOOK. I will try not to give up too much but I feel like if you buy this movie you should know all the stuff they left our and the superficial way they made this deep movie (shame on the directors).Katniss & her sister were STARVING-almost to the point of death because their father was killed in a mining explosion and their mother 'checked out'.  The mom literally wouldn't move, no dinner, no taking care of her small children, she just zoned out after the dad was killed.  So Katniss was trying to sell anything they owned for any food and no one would help, no one would even look at the 'seam kid=trash'.  She was in the pouring rain, skin and bones trying to sell some threadbare clothing for any food possible when Peeta came out to feed the pigs at their house in the village.  They were the bakers in the village.  Peeta saw the starving girl, took pity on her, and went back into the bakery (don't want to give away too much so skipped some detail in here), came out and threw her some loaves of burned bread.  They took in each other for a while and then she left and was able to feed herself and her sister.  She even `made' her mother eat something.Katniss & Gale-they met on accident in the woods and became hunting partners as she could use a bow like an extension of her own arm  & she knew what plants were for what, as her father taught her.  Gale was a master at traps, had strength and was a fierce protector.  The forged a friendship based on need.  That grew into a friendship of trust, respect, need and a bond in which few know-they would protect each other at all costs and their families.  Only one of them was in love with the other.  Katniss was the only reason her family didn't starve and die.After the Reaping in the rooms BEFORE they were carted off in the train Peeta's dad came to see Katniss and not his son.  He brought Katniss cookies for the trip and told her that he would make sure that her sister wouldn't starve.  That this stranger to her and her family would do this really hit home with Katniss.  This is another detail that later will be needed.The train ride was HUGE!  This was as important as the Games in my opinion!  This is where Peeta (the whole time) showed that he was pure of heart, genuinely a good person, protective of Katniss (which no one knew why), take charge in a way people just listened and normally agreed.  He was very persuasive, had a way with people and Katniss was having a real issue not liking him.  He did little things here and there, tried to help her here and there, protected her against Haymitch and took care of things that as a Tribute shouldn't have cared about for his competition.  He said through it all that he wouldn't let the Capital change him, he would be him to the end even if it ended up killing him.  He wouldn't give them the satisfaction, he was very passive aggressive in a good way.  He has a huge personality that you don't realize until he is actually worked his way to you, LOL.  This was a VERY deep character!  Katniss and him have lots of different interactions that develop into other things later.  Unfort, most will see these as shallow since they didn't include any of this.  Peeta is a very genuine, caring, good person, and the movie made him seem very shallow and blah.During the training, there was so much left out & other things that were not even in the book...I.E. they were told by Haymitch to NOT show what they were good at!  They were to only show that to the judges at the end when the other tributes were not around.  There was a reason for this which they didn't show either.  This whole scene to me felt forced and very awkward like they were ad-libbing their lines.The prep crews were very intricate throughout the train & training, where Katniss formed bonds with these people and how they transformed her `painfully' into what she became.  In the film you didn't understand WHY on earth she would cling to Cinna who was just a stylist for an outfit for the hunger games, a Capital person who was putting her into this death situation...because they left all the stuff on the train out.  It looked forced and out of place.  This will need to be known later or parts to come wont make a bit of sense.Haymitch, they really did this character incorrect.  Haymitch is a JERK!  HUGE JERK!  There are reasons why but I don't want to give it away.  He was a severe drunk, couldn't hardly walk or move about, and constantly drunk (I mean drunk & falling off stages).  He was abrasive, crude, rude, obnoxious, & loud.  His interaction with Katniss is so rude, that you wonder why he is so mean to her.  Peeta has to take care of him a couple times as he is such a jerk.  He is not at all what is portrayed in the movie.  It took Peeta & Katniss almost going after him to get him to agree to a truce to train them.  In the movie, he didn't seem that bad.  NO he is a JERK (there are reasons which are not going to make sense later).When they do the chariot part I was horrified when they did the whole hand scene!  It was forced, shallow and was only for show!  Peeta did this as he was trying to calm Katniss, it was a genuine act of friendship to help her out, NOT FOR SHOW! She liked it in a way and she didn't understand why he was so nice.  It made them strong together.  By this time she was really starting to trust him, and his judgment which they totally didn't show throughout this.  Their relationship wasn't defined yet but there was something whether friendship, need, strength, like, whatever, but there was definitely something there, not just for show.  I actually yelled at the TV (WHAT) when he said that!Peeta wanted to protect Katniss so much that he was with the Careers as a strategy to protect her, knowing they would attack her first and he could stop them. The scenes in the Arena looked forced between Peeta & Katniss where the book was very smooth (because the book showed the relationship before and the movie tried to just add it in).  They related to each other, they depended on each other, they looked out for each other, they formed a stronger bond based upon their growing relationship.  It was not forced, it was not shallow, it was not just for show.  Then when she did kiss him, they totally made that SHALLOW.  That kiss was not shallow, it totally shook them both up!  Here again they took out the feeling of the book.  After this point Katniss didn't know what to think, she just knew something was different.  The last scene in the arena, was again forced (it was with no feeling), where the book had feeling!  I don't want to say because it's a major part, but it was not like the book at all especially the scene after.The mockingjay pin really ticked me off.  Katniss didn't buy it at the hob.  She was given it by her only `girl' friend.  She was so surprised and moved at this gesture.  She didn't even realize how much of a friend this girl was until that moment.Casting--Pres. Snow-FANTASTIC casting!  I saw him and immediately knew which character he was.  Same with Gale.  He was just about what I would have expected him to be. Great casting on Gale, totally believable!  Effie, Mom, Cinna, dad, game maker, the other Tributes -again great casting.  Katniss, she looked the part, most of the time she was believable but there was something missing.  Maybe it was that they screwed up the scripts and she was working with what she had.  I wish she had read the book and was more like the Katniss in there, that way I would totally see her in that part.  Haymitch-totally wrong in my opinion.  I love Woody, but not as Haymitch, he is too nice, too good to play a rough, nasty, jerk.  Now again like Katniss...it might have been the script and maybe he didn't read the book to get what Haymitch was really like.  But it was not believable at all to me.  Peeta...oh Peeta...I like this actor...however not as Peeta.  I didn't believe anything about him, not the way he interacted with the people, Katniss, or when he was trying to get her to run.  It all looked forced and out of place, he just didn't convince me he was Peeta.  Peeta & Katniss had NO chemistry whatsoever.  Peeta ended up after the series to be one of my favorite people when I loved Gale from the get go in the book.  They did the biggest disservice to him in my opinion.As a movie on its own, I thought it was good.  However, because I had read the book, been in the lives of these characters and felt what they felt and had been in their heads because of the book I was annoyed all throughout the movie.  They took the feeling out of the characters, and the movie where the books were FULL of feelings (how could they not with children being put into death situations).  I was very disappointed in the director & the author for allowing it.That's my opinion, take it as you may :-)

reviewText: I've never read the series, so when I saw the movie everything about the story was new to me.That being said, I think they managed to convey the story of what the world was about pretty well, for someone who's never read the books.Basically, it's set in a dystopian future world, under a sort of fascist rule. Apparently, some parts of their country rebelled against the leadership 75 years prior, and now as punishment each year 2 kids between ages 12-18 are picked as "tributes," representing their home districts.Then, all the tributes are let loose in a Lord of the Flies-vs-Survivor way, and they basically have to bond with each other to survive, then kill each other off until there is one remaining victor. This person then gets showered in riches.The movie (and book, I suppose) touch upon very philosphical ideas, such as how much power should a state have? It also touches on the idea of how our mass media works. These 24 kids who are picked as "tributes" (against their will...it's a lottery system) are paraded around the public like show-ponies. These kids have to fight for their lives, they're terrified, and the crowd is whooping it up and "cheering," reveling in the spectacle.It really makes you think about our celebrity and media culture.And the action scenes, where the kids are trying to survive, are great.I'll just end this by saying I rented this movie on Comcast OnDemand. It was so good I bought my own copy of the DVD.
summary: Never read the books, loved the movie

reviewText: One thing I couldn't help thinking, while watching the movie, is just how much the movie seemed lika a republican paradise! You have people who are literally dirt poor, from many "districts", far - far away from the wealthy. The super-clean and extremely wealthy use the poor for growing their food and generating their power and oh yeah - "entertainment"! Brutal and bloody entertainment to satisfy the sadistic needs of the upper class. This movie reminds me of a high-tech futuristic fusion of reality tv and bloodsport in the great coliseums of the Roman empire! glad it's just a movie. At least for now!I only watched this movie because im a fan of Jennifer Lawrence and im soooooooo glad I got my ticket. The gritty hardcore nature of the film is the kind of style I gravitate to just like when I watch the first 2 minutes of Battlestar Galactica(circa 2004). I've been hooked ever since and now im hooked on the Hunger Games!I loved every minute of "The Hunger Games", and I can't wait for more to come!!!

reviewText: I read the book about a week before the movie came out because I was interested what the hype was about and I'm glad I did because if not most of the movie would have gotten right over my head.The movie seems to be more a companion to the book then a standalone movie and even in this it fails for the most part due to the wodden acting of some hunky teenage pretty boys (I mean come on, the Gale character meets pretty much every stereotype of a moody self obsessed teenager you can think of, Peeta seems desperate for the heroines approval). in the books these guys are supposed to be emanciated on the brink of starvation for the most part and here we have an 'all jock' cast pretending to do battle.Which gets me to the battle scenes, the book has a certain grittiness and violence to it, but here we see an almost G-rated version. Rue apparently died from what can best be described as a scratch  you'd normally put a bandaid on and get on your merry way with a song on your lips. Action scenes were usually spiced up by doing the shaky camera thing and now that I think of it most other scenes used that 'feature' as well.Now that I'm writing this I think I have been to generous with giving it two stars, but I can't be bothered to go back and change it. It'll be a hit with the teenagers and if you want to get your girl all ready for a make out session by all means go for it, but for anybody else I'd not recommend it....

reviewText: No way should this be dragged out for 2 hours and 10 minutes. I squirmed. The entire first hour is slower than cold molasses. Then, after more tedium, we finally get to the games part, but still I did not see the light. My guess is this appeals to the same demographic that is making a hit out of the Twilight books and films, i.e., young semi-educated women. Actually, I found this all rather amusing at many points which I'm sure were unintended. It's a "Survivor" rip-off, made into a little low-dose science fiction, with some overlay of social commentary about haves and have-nots in conflict. reviewText: This is a most amazing picture. Catniss Everdeen seems like a clever survivor but she is much more than that.  She has a heart determined to save her sister and protect her family from the Capitol's fierce and blatant use of young adults as gladiators in a no win  contest. Only one player can win and she doesn't want to play their game but is forced to comply because of the Capitols technology.Even though she attempts to save a young girl from another district in the end it is for nothing or maybe it isn't.  Her determination caused riots in some of the other districts run and ruled by the Capitol.  The winners of a nuclear war which devastated the world 74 years ago,the Capitol is cruel, selfish and cares nothing for the districts who lost. They dine on the best of food, wear outrageous costumes and only care for their own entertainment."May the odds be ever in your favor" as you watch Catniss destroy the game for the Capitol.

reviewText: IN A SENTENCE: I really enjoyed the books, and felt the first movie did a great job of condensing the sensational and unconventional novel for the big screen.I saw the movie with my two grown daughters, and all of us are "Hunger Games" aficionados (I'm almost 60, and my kids are 27 and 30).  We all loved the movie, discussed the film as we drove home, and we found few real problems.First of all, the acting was terrific.  Jennifer Lawrence did a fine job capturing Katniss, though I didn't get the same feeling of anger perennially seething under her skin.  That bothered me, but my daughters had no problems there.I thought Josh Hutcherson and Liam Hemsworth as Peeta and Gale, respectively, were both terrific.  Gale's part was very minimal, but he was certainly the right actor for the part.  Peeta is spot on as the "doughy" baker whose lack of skills as a fighter are counterbalanced by his wisdom at assessing the politics necessary to survival.Lenny Kravitz was a great choice as Cinna, and I would have given him more screen time.  In fact, I was extremely pleased with the entire Capital scenes...their depraved innocence, their stupidity, their love of spectacle, their entire sense of action without consequence--I felt Director Gary Ross and his compatriots did these scenes justice.  Donald Sutherland as President Snow, Elizabeth Banks as Effie Trinket, Stanley Tucci as Caesar Flickerman and Wes Bentley as Seneca Crane--all accurately cast and cleverly played.Willow Shields was fine as Primrose, but her role did not ask for a lot in this movie.  I believe the reasons they picked her will become apparent by the third movie.There was not too much to complain about here: Understandably, the book did a far better job at getting into Katniss' head, especially when it came to the relationship she had with Peeta.  It's there, but her struggles with her feelings are not detailed, and because of that I would guess that those unfamiliar with the novels will not catch on to the problems she had with authenticity of her feelings.Also there, but decreased, is Haymitch's drunkenness.  He is still a drinker, but it presents nowhere near the impact here that it did in the novel.  He overcomes his dependency rapidly, almost as if it is simply an affectation and nothing more.I didn't think they did justice to the role of Katniss' mom, played by Paula Malcomson.  This is especially true when it came to the period of mourning after her husband's death when she "checked out" mentally and left her kids to survive on their own.  It was mentioned, but I do not believe it was not choreographed well enough for those who did not read the book to to gather its import.There are other significant changes, and many will have to be weighed as the movie's sequels move along.  One I'm interested in is the small change made concerning this movie's lack of follow up to the hovercraft scene witnessed by Katniss and Gale.  They showed the hovercraft, but there was nothing further in this movie...I'm hoping there might be a clever twist coming up.  I'm sorry I can't be more clear about this; I feel it would be too much of a spoiler to go into here.All in all, this movie is very faithful to the book, and it makes me really "hunger" for the sequels.  What will the setting of the second Hunger Game look like?  What about the bunker in the third movie?  What about the urban warfare in movie 4?  The sewers?I'm really looking forward to it all.
summary: Hunger Games leaves you hungry for more

reviewText: For the record - I am a HUGE Hunger Games fan and have been of the books for over 2 years. Please do not read this as a rant, but rather a fans opinion.This movie is garbage in the representation of the books. It was created specifically with Twilight fan-girls in mind. The first chunk of the movie is very, very slow and does not explain anything well. If you did not read the book (or books, actually, as the movie jumps a bit ahead on features), I cannot see something really understanding what is going on. At the very least, the true meaning from the book is lost."HEY! Movies can't be exactly like the books!" you may say. Yes, I agree with this but to a point. The books revolve around the main fact: the Capital forces two children from each district to brutally murder each other to survive. The film makers took this and decided - for the young children audience - that the kids would fluff each other to death. Deaths magically become fuzzy or shaky, with music or odd sound overlayed to the scene.I went to see this movie opening night at a nice theater - it cost me about $20 a reserved seat which I purchased first available day. It was packed 90% with teenage girls who screamed over the barely-there deaths and gasped out loud over the kiss which, if you read the book, is not a "real" kiss. Before the movie 12 year old girls were running around yelling "TEAM PEETA!".Greed took advantage of what had amazing potential. Money was the key factor - young girls will be running out to buy the "team" shirts and action figure toys. A rated R movie would have been true to the story, but would generate a mere fraction in sales.
summary: I wanted so badly to like it
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am one of the many that really enjoyed The Hunger Games series, so of course I was excited and nervous to see the movie. In short, I thought they did a very excellent job at it. The casting was spot on. I think every actor fit perfectly with the character they were playing. I really enjoyed the movie and thought it was done really well. There were quite a few things left out or condensed, but all in all I was not very disappointed.Now for the long of it and there will be spoilers so reader beware ;)There was barely any beginning to this movie. Everything happens very fast. You are introduced to some of the important characters, but they hardly feel important as Katniss and Peeta were whisked off to the Hunger Games. I think it worked okay for the movie, but it makes Peeta the logical love intrest, so it sort of cuts down on the internal struggle Katniss has picking between them. Next Madge? Anyone? Anyone? No Madge?! Why not. I think that Madge played a subtly important role and I was quite dismayed that they blotted out her existence. So the tributes are getting ready at the Capitol and I just felt like there wasn't much between Katniss and Peeta then. I think all the emotions that happen pre-games is what made them such dynamic characters in the books. You could see that they sort of become friends and then you see Peeta slow betrayal of that trust, that makes you wonder about him. I just felt like the character interactions could have been a bit stronger for the movie. I did love Cinna and Katniss, but again their movie relationship seemed a bit shallow and abrupt. There were also no transports for the dead bodies, which seemed a bit odd to take out, but ultimately didn't ruin the movie. I wished that there was more about Foxface but again, wasn't crucial to the story so they took it out. There were tons of things I loved about this movie though, like the command central for the games. It was very interesting to see the behind the scenes of the games. As easy as thinking it and they could do it. I'll mention the cast again, because the acting was great and they fit the characters so well. Definitely check out this movie. It got me so excited for the next three movies. I'm super excited to see the arena in Catching Fire. It's going to be crazy. Watching Mockingjay will be great too, because it's such a different story from the first two. So much happens and it's all very interesting. Anyways. the movie was lovely even though they left out a lot of things. My hope is that the relationships will get stronger in the next movie and then this series will be epic, like the books.

reviewText: The Hunger Games, Directed by Gary Ross (Seabiscuit), is a real witches brew of many genre! I see "Alice in Wonderland" caricatures like Stanley Tucci's over-the-top flaming flamboyant bouffant blue haired talk show host, Caesar Flickerman and Elizabeth Banks as the apply named comic-book fashionesta Effie Trinket.Then we have a pinch of "Lord of the Rings" grandeur, a dash of ruthless "Lord of the Flies" child thrown for cinematic atmosphere, a touch of "Harry Potter" fantasy and a big dose of TV's "Survivor" reality show! All of this bubbled up in one big cauldron of non-stop adventure!Our heroine, attractive young, capable, 16 year old Katniss Everdeen, played by Jennifer Lawrence, sets out early one misty morning crossing secretly into the "forbidden zone" to hunt. Armed only with her trusty bow and arrows, she stalks and takes aim at an innocent doe with deer eyes. I can't bear it! But, out of nowhere, who should appear but her tall dark prince charmer/neighbor Gale Hawthorne, played by hunky Liam Hemsworth! Wise beyond his years, he proceeds to demonstrate to her how she might put to better use her skills as an effective archer, in the future. Hint! hint!The forest is lush, green and serene paralleled to the "highly advanced metropolis" in which "The Capitol" is located; This, in brutal contrast to the barren wasteland of Panem City where Katniss is forced to live with her mother and younger sister.While we are slowly being introduced into this sterile "post-apocalyptic" environment, there is an ever present underlying ominous pale, looming over the town folk! Soon enough we discover that they are preparing for an inevitable event.Everyone will be summoned to The Capitol square, where each year one boy and one girl will be selected as "Tribute". From each of 12 districts a pair will be chosen through a lottery to participate in what amounts to a death match. The repeating anthem being "May all the luck be in your favor". The event, akin to the Superbowl, will be viewed on big screen monitors for the enjoyment of all to see.Voila, The Hunger Games are born!The rest of the principals in this entertaining cast o heroes victims and villains consists of Josh Hutcherson as Peeta Mellark, the unlikely boy tribute from district 12. Katniss young sister is originally picked but Katniss herself will later volunteer as tribute sparing her sister.Rounding out the cast are Mentor to our two tributes, Haymitch Abernathy, played craftily by Woody Harrelson. A semi-unrecognizable Lenny Kravitz as Cinna, aka groom and stylist to the stars; Wes Bentley as the inept minion Seneca Crane to the supreme leader of "The Capitol" gang, President Snow, played by Donald Sutherland who is always a joy.I never expected the clever twists and turns, the way the story skillfully unfolds, the stunning visuals and the inspiring soundtrack!Although i felt it lacking in some strange inexplicable way, it was a surprisingly well crafted PG-13 syfy-ish romp in the woods from the starting countdown all the way to the winners circle!Enjoy!
summary: -The Hunger Games...Not Unlike the Downvote Game-
